discourse_list.title: MIP85: LDO to MKR OTC Swap

content.content: MIP85: LDO-to-MKR OTC Swap  Preamble MIP#: 85 Title: LDO-to-MKR OTC Swap Author(s): @rune Contributors: @juan, @retro Tags: endgame Type:  Status: Withdrawn Date Proposed: 2022-09-07 Date Ratified: <yyyy-mm-dd> Dependencies: Replaces:  Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mipxx-ldo-to-mkr-otc-swap/17714 Ratification Poll URL:    Sentence Summary MIP85 is an optional Endgame Launch Plan MIP that provides the DAO an opportunity to trade MKR for LDO, at a discount, to jumpstart the Protocol Owned Vault Emulation.  Paragraph Summary This MIP is completely optional, if it is rejected it doesn’t impact the approval of the Endgame Plan. The proposal is to swap 20 million LDO from Rune’s holding company, Calteram Holdings for MKR in the Maker Pause Proxy at a large discount in Maker’s favor. The LDO was originally obtained as early-stage investor in Lido.  Component Summary MIP85c1: OTC Swap Party Definitions Defines the parties involved in the OTC swap. MIP85c2: OTC Swap Commitment Defines the commitment of each party involved in the OTC swap. MIP85c3: OTC Swap Process Defines the process for the OTC swap. MIP85c4: OTC Swap Exchange Rate Defines how the Exchange Rate will be used in the OTC swap. MIP85c5: OTC Swap Exchange Rate Calculation Defines how the Exchange Rate will be calculated for the OTC swap. MIP85c6: MIP4 Amendment Block Clause & Automatic Depreciation Blocks any Governance actions from revoking or modifying the terms of the OTC swap if the MIP is ratified.  Motivation LDO has 3-5x the liquidity of MKR and is currently one of hottest tokens among smart money, and it is extremely hard to get ahold of large allocations. Maker owning a large LDO stake helps make the economic dynamics of the early Endgame Plan come full circle by giving Maker exposure to the increased adoption of Lido Staked ETH, and provides the Protocol Owned Vault Emulation a lot of starting collateral to build a larger position, to help increase the decentralization of Dai.  Specification / Proposal Details  MIP85c1: OTC Swap Party Definitions This MIP establishes an OTC deal between MakerDAO and Calteram Holdings.  MIP85c2: OTC Swap Commitment If the MIP is approved, MakerDAO Governance commits to send MKR from the Pause Proxy after receiving LDO from Calteram Holdings to a predetermined Ethereum Address.  MIP85c3: OTC Swap Process The transfers will be in two rounds, with the first swap of about 75% of the amount to be done immediately following the successful vote, and the second swap of what remains of the 20000000 LDO happening around December 17, 2022 (due to remaining vesting periods). The exchange rate will be the same in both transactions, and will follow the MIP85c5.  MIP85c4: OTC Swap Exchange Rate The exact rate of the swap will be locked at the moment the vote ends successfully. It will be determined based on the formula in MIP85c5 that gives a higher discount to Maker if MKR is lower relative to LDO, and a lower discount if MKR is higher relative to LDO.  MIP85c5: OTC Swap Exchange Rate Calculation The exchange rate is calculated by looking at the official exchange rate of LDO per MKR on Coingecko at the moment the MIP is approved, and then applying a bonus to the amount of LDO per MKR according to the formula below. The result determines how much MKR Maker Governance must return for LDO received following the passing of this MIP.  Increase to LDO per MKR exchange rate based on relative exchange rates:  MKR/LDO 751+ = +10% MKR/LDO 701-750 = +15% MKR/LDO 651-700 = +20% MKR/LDO 601-650 = +25% MKR/LDO 551-600 = +30% MKR/LDO 501-550 = +35% MKR/LDO 451-500 = +41% MKR/LDO 401-450 = +47% MKR/LDO 351-400 = +53% MKR/LDO 301-350 = +59% MKR/LDO 251-300 = +65% MKR/LDO 201-250 = +71% MKR/LDO 151-200 = +77% MKR/LDO 101-150 = +83% MKR/LDO 51-100 = +90% MKR/LDO 1-50 = +100%
content.GPT-summary: MIP85 proposes an optional Endgame Launch Plan for MakerDAO to trade MKR for LDO at a discount to jumpstart the Protocol Owned Vault Emulation. The proposal is to swap 20 million LDO from Rune's holding company, Calteram Holdings, for MKR in the Maker Pause Proxy. The MIP establishes the parties involved, the commitment of each party, the process, and the exchange rate calculation. The proposal aims to increase the decentralization of Dai and give Maker exposure to the increased adoption of Lido Staked ETH. The post also includes a formula for calculating the exchange rate.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
None

content.content: (Reserved for LDO to MKR OTC Swap’s Summary by GovAlpha).

I have been pondering this proposal for a while and I think it has the potential to create a narrative of self interest. Restricting this swap to a known entity could also serve to reduce the legitimacy of the endgame plan. Something which I believe is the opposite of the intention of this proposal. To create peace and stability surrounding a strategic direction. My proposal for amendment would therefore be to allow other participants that wish to join a swap on the same terms as presented, do so. Practically this could be set up as a book building process, with either a max cap on  MKR distributed, or without a cap. Set a deadline for commitment and conduct the swap for all parties involved at a specified time. That should remove any doubt whether this is a deal that is particularly favorable to one side. Given the sizable premium presented my assumption is that interest from other parties will be limited.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: JustinCase:  have been pondering this proposal for a while and I think it has the potential to create a narrative of self interest. Restricting this swap to a known entity could also serve to reduce the legitimacy of the endgame plan. Something which I believe is the opposite of the intention of this proposal. To create peace and stability surrounding a strategic direction.   I’ve also have put a lot of thought into this MIP—and I don’t have all the right answers, but this is how I’m thinking about it. More than likely I’m misunderstanding your message here, Excuse me if I am—but when deeply thinking about this proposal, I believe the intention of this MIP is to allow MakerDAO to accumulate LDO for the Protocol Owned Vault Emulation (POVE) via OTC versus using the dssKiln which could be front-run, sandwiched, and every thing else in between. Adding LDO increases the Surplus Buffer along with DAI, AAVE, ENS, and whatever else I’m forgetting (VELO on OP) that makes up the treasury.     JustinCase:  My proposal for amendment would therefore be to allow other participants that wish to join a swap on the same terms as presented, do so. Practically this could be set up as a book building process, with either a max cap on MKR distributed, or without a cap. Set a deadline for commitment and conduct the swap for all parties involved at a specified time.   Personally, and this is Not Financial Advice—I would not swap my LDO for MKR at a discount. Or even at Par. First of all,  I believe LidoDAO has the opportunity to blossom—it’s very early for that community and they seem eager to contribute to the future of Web3. Second—also because I’m a big believer in diversification—which IMO is an alternative way to think about the acquisition of  LDO when thinking about diversifying MakerDAO’s treasury. And last but not least, this actually works in favor of diversifying LDO token ownership. Their have been many public  complaints from the ecosystem about Lido having too large of a pie, when it comes to validating/staking services (responsible for approximately 30%) for ETH 2.0. By acquiring LDO, you extend the token ownership and diversified to a group of MKR token owners that can help in the decentralization of LidoDAO. Who knows, perhaps some of the Delegates here can get Delegated LDO and help shape the future of LidoDAO.

content.content: Writing as a community member, not ISCU official communication I think the only way this MIP makes sense is if we buy into the urgency of POVE/MIP84. Since I cannot support MIP84, as written, I am not even interested in the MKR/LDO exchange rate. That is to say, I think that voters should consider whether the DAO wants to own that much LDO (to add to useless ENS and stkAAVE) before considering whether the trade makes financial sense.

content.content: psychonaut:  I think that voters should consider whether the DAO wants to own that much LDO (to add to useless ENS and stkAAVE )   Opinions mine, not GovAlpha’s but this is a very good point. Holding onto other projects’ tokens is just additional governance overhead in terms of what to do with them. The discussion around ENS was similar at the time and now largely sits forgotten in the treasury. The amount of LDO suggested here is additionally impossible to offboard quickly without incurring huge slippage.

It is of course possible we view this on different time scales, but selling would seem to do the opposite of the stated goals.

content.content: Well we would be acquiring the LDO at a discount, so MakerDAO could make money off the spread. In return, Rune would acquire more influence over MakerDAO. It is just a possibility though. Rune may vote against MakerDAO selling LDO.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: It would do both of those things. We would cause increased adoption of stETH over a long period of time (by buying it as a DAO), at the very least until we upgrade ETHD to be more than just a wrapper. This increased adoption is captured in LDO and should manifest in increased long term gains. We would obviously sell after this, if we wanted to sell. For the second point, the key word is “starting”. It would literally be the difference between initial collateral that supports $72M of stETH purchases and initial collateral that supports $100M of stETH purchases.

content.content: A founder doing a significant economic transaction with his own protocol raises some key issues.  The potential conflicts of interest are real and challenges to good goverance. Will it be be a fair market arm’s length transaction?  If not it will look like an insider deal that exploits other MKR holders. How can Maker evaluate if its a fair market value transaction?  Selling a sizable LIDO stake would require a price well below the current market price and buying a sizable MKR stake would be well above current market prices. Can a credible 3rd party opine on what the LIDO discounted price will be?  And the higher MKR price should be? Also is there any reason for Maker to want to acquire LIDO?  A separate vote perhaps? Does Maker want to issue a larger share of MKR to a large holder?  Seems like another vote? Finally the proposer is conflicted on these key votes.  Should he recuse his direct MKR votes and delegated votes?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal
None of the topics listed match

My calculations is 80k MKR. are votes gonna be skewed to a single party? If this goes through i sincerely think everyone can just stop contribution to the community

content.content: fumoffuXx:  if this vote goes through. LIDO will have a significant stake in MAKERDAO   No, the proposal is for Rune to retain the MKR after swapping LDO from his holding company. This would add to Rune’s stake as one of (if not the) largest recognizable MKR holders.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Eumenes:  Also is there any reason for Maker to want to acquire LIDO? A separate vote perhaps?   There was no reason for Maker to purchase LDO at any point and there still isn’t. Directly buying stETH makes sense for POVE, buying LDO does not. It’s a governance token and does not have long term value accrual mechanism. It seems Rune wants to exit his LDO position and Maker is the only way to do it without losing a shit ton to market slippage. Additionally, MKR is at an all time low in ETH terms so great deal again for anyone buying MKR. The protocol is not financially better off after this deal.     rune:  Increase to LDO per MKR exchange rate based on relative exchange rates:  MKR/LDO 751+ = +10%    This is not very clear. I post what I understand from it below. Does this mean that after 750 MKR have been transferred, the remaining MKR is sold for LDO at a 10% discount compared to the price on CoinGecko? Without slippage, 20M LDO is worth $36M at the moment. In MKR terms, that’s 55,300 MKR. Ignoring the first 750 which is basically a rounding error, what this seems to say is that the entire 55,000 MKR is sold for LDO with just a 10% discount on Coingecko’s price? If so, I don’t see how this is a large discount in Maker’s favor - 10% is peanuts when it means acquiring an asset we otherwise wouldn’t for 75% of all MKR in the treasury.     rune:  The exchange rate is calculated by looking at the official exchange rate of LDO per MKR on Coingecko  at the moment the MIP is approved   And if all this isn’t enough, with the amount of LDO available here to Rune, it’s very easy to manipulate liquidity and artificially lower the price on CoinGecko just before the MIP passes. There’s no way to prevent the market from being manipulated and for Maker to lose even more on this deal. This is insane!
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

None of the topics listed match

content.content: Finally someone comes out and says it. Another raw deal for the DAO, especially when you consider whatever the hell this End Game thing is.
same deal? centralisation much?

A lot of tin foil hat vibes in this post. Take a deep breath. If rune is doing this to acquire more MKR tokens, he will be even more invested in the success of the MKR token, so it wouldn’t make sense to cuck the DAO.     squid:  It seems Rune wants to exit his LDO position and Maker is the only way to do it without losing a shit ton to market slippage.   To add to a MKR position that he would have even more trouble exiting (lower liquidity + public eye)?     squid:  This is not very clear. I post what I understand from it below. Does this mean that after 750 MKR have been transferred, the remaining MKR is sold for LDO at a 10% discount compared to the price on CoinGecko?   It was clear to me. You have it way wrong. Look at this quote in the OP:     rune:  based on relative exchange rates   Price of MKR is 630.82 right now. Price of LDO is 1.81. The relative exchange rate is 630.82/1.81 or 348.5. This means if the MIP passed today, we would fall into the following bucket and get a FIFTY NINE percent bonus on the LDO acquisition.     rune:  MKR/LDO 301-350 = +59%       squid:  And if all this isn’t enough, with the amount of LDO available here to Rune, it’s very easy to manipulate liquidity and artificially lower the price on CoinGecko just before the MIP passes. There’s no way to prevent the market from being manipulated and for Maker to lose even more on this deal.   This is a somewhat legitimate concern but we could account for this multiple ways, one of which would be to dox the address the LDO tokens are being held in & have a provision which prevents those from moving. Another would be to take some sort of moving average at the time of MIP approval. Edit: actually this last one is not a legit concern. If rune manipulated the price of LDO lower, the LDO bonus % would be less, but the base exchange rate would be much more favorable for Maker (and less for rune). Both the bonus % and the overall exchange rate is set when the MIP passes.

We should be competitors of Lido at this point, we have all the tools and people to create our staking service AND MINT DAI, is just the best plan to follow and no single person here see it.

content.content: RoFz:  why we would want LDO in first place?   One reason is that LDO, in contrast to MKR, actually enters our treasury and can be an asset on our balance sheet. This asset can then be used to generate revenue.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: The points regarding the pricing and discount by @lyt above are correct. Hard to respond to all the weird hateful comments here but one thing to point out is that Lido is the only altcoin with a sound decentralized business case that actually has pmf and is sustainable, meaning it can be used as collateral in the Protocol Owned Vault and would contribute meaningfully to generating more decentralized Dai. It is also revenue generating, taking a cut from all Lido Staked ETH and eventually paying it out as dividends once this is activated by governance… which is why there is very good synergy between basing the entire economic foundation of the early Endgame Plan on stETH and then owning a large stake of LDO. (not to mention the security provided of being able to influence lido governance both through the stETH (due to the dual voting) and also LDO voting itself)

content.content: I will also edit this MIP before the frozen period to remove any mention of a specific counterparty, and instead change it to an “open offer” that will be available for anyone to take advantage of by sending LDO to the Pause Proxy, for up to 20000 LDO at a fixed exchange rate, available for up to 1 week following the MIPs ratification.

content.content: These questions are already answered elsewhere on the forum. I would encourage you to use the search function prior to posting in the future.   Not minted   MakerDAO will not use MKR as collateral for Dai. It could use LDO. This exchange would allow MakerDAO to mint Dai it could otherwise not.   Rune is a minority MKR participant based on the global token distribution. He is actively working to decentralize MKR distribution as a core and immutable feature of the endgame plan. He is the only large MKR holder actively working toward this goal.

content.content: sound like a major conflict of interest to me     MadShills:  These questions are already answered elsewhere on the forum. I would encourage you to use the search function prior to posting in the future.   No offense, but all resource should be linked to a single source to mitigate governance complexity to be compliant with the goal to simplify governance matters. In addition, when a MIP is proposed, shouldn’t the creator of the MIP predict expected questions or queries which will be asked by the community? as this would show how much consideration has been thought into it. instead of giving the community a feeling it was just thought out on the fly. As currently its so reactive based that its like the community doing all the critical thinking for the creator, this applies to most MIPs.

content.content: Reminder that this proposal will enter its Frozen Period on Wednesday, September 28 at 23:59 UTC. Substantive modifications beyond that date will render the proposal ineligible for the upcoming Governance Cycle / reset its Frozen Period, as the case may be. <> <>  <>

Besides the issues being raised about centralization of power in the DAO and the fact that Rune will be voting on this proposal… how exactly does Maker determine when to sell LDO? Let’s say we agree to this swap and end up with a chunk of LDO. What criteria are we going to establish on when to sell LDO? Has anyone sat down to think about what the intrinsic value of LDO is?

content.content: Well unlike MKR LDO is actually generating yield by diverting stEth from their stakers. So its a good deal. MKR is not doing anything to acrue value. Atleast LDO does. This way MakerDao gets the privilege of holding a governance token that acrues value. Its an enticing prospect. Seems like a succesful concept. Pure governance tokens like MKR/Uni will inevitably lose value in relation to tokens that generate revenue. If you are unable to create a token that is succesful just buy it from someone that knows what they are doing.

content.content: Pure governance tokens fundamental value  is limited, protocols know that and are moving towards revenue/fee generation or burning again. E.g. UNI is turning on fees and potentially Maker can burn MKR again, once revenue metrics improve, but seems lower priority given prioritization on growth and adoption surplus buffer requirements. The main question though is not whether LDO is a good token or not (I agree that its a great business model), the question is whether we are acquiring it at a fair price for long-term growth, basically what intrinsic value (i.e. DCF) was calculated to determine this is a good buy above all the other assets that treasury can hold.

content.content: I am withdrawing this MIP as I no longer think the extra MKR will be necessary to prevent harmful flip flopping on the Endgame plan if the Endgame Plan Approval MIPs are passed. There is also clearly a lot of confusion and lack of understanding of the value proposition of LDO and the synergy between Lido and Maker.

content.content: rune:  I am withdrawing this MIP   CC @MIP-Editors
That’s truly unfortunate news but understandable.

Ah good to know. Well I kinda expected as much. I kinda invested under the premise that MKR holders are entitled to protocol profits as it made MKR stand out as one of the few tokens with value acrual. But this idea has been totally scrapped? Well I am disappointed to say the least. The fact that there was no meaningful growth and all the profits were diverted to other people with the promise that in the future at some point MKR holders will get compensated for the risk they are taking was something that still made me hold on to my tokens. The added regulatory risk, the inevitable failure to comply with US stablecoin regulations and the move away from the core principles. All that coming so neatly together at the alltime ratio Eth-MKR low is just the icing on the cake.

content.content: I just wrote a post which details the ability for Maker to leverage StakeWise’s new upgrade to stake its own ETH and benefit from liquid staking at the same time.     StakeWise V3 <> Maker Governance       StakeWise has just announced its V3 upgrade which will be very relevant for Maker and its plans to utilise ETH staking within the PCV and ETHD. For context, StakeWise is undergoing a major upgrade and will soon transition to a fully permissionless protocol in a new two-layered model for liquid staking. This model will allow anyone who can run an Ethereum node to access the benefits of liquid staking on their own ETH or offer liquid ETH staking to their delegators. A link to the full announcement…

3rd party asking questions about proposal
